tit.e: Kan (An Unit of Weight and Currency)

sen.j: 貫（かん）は、尺貫法における質量の単位、また江戸時代以前の秤量銀貨の通貨の単位である。
sen.e: "Kan" is a weight unit in the traditional Japanese system of weights and measures, and it was also a Japanese currency unit for the silver coin used as the currency by weight before the Edo period.
sen.cmt: （注①）・・・「尺貫法」は、狭義では日本独特の度量衡の単位系を、広義では東アジア共通の度量衡の単位系を指します。ここは狭義に解しています。（注②）・・・「秤量（ひょうりょう）銀貨」の定訳は見つかりませんでしたが、「秤量貨幣」の研究社・大和英の訳（currency by weight)を参考に"silver coin used as currency by weight"としました。（注③）真珠の質量単位としては現在も「貫」が使われていますので、質量単位としての「貫」の部分は現在形にしています。
sen.e: Kan is a weight unit in the traditional Japanese system of weights and measures, and it was also a Japanese currency unit for the silver coin used as the currency by weight before the Edo period.

sen.j: 江戸時代の一貫は分銅の実測によれば3.746～3.747キログラム(kg)である。
sen.e: By weighing "fundo" (counterweight used in currency exchange), we know that 1 kan in the Edo period was set at 3.746 - 3.747 kilograms.

sen.j: 質量単位の貫は1000匁に当たり、明治時代に 1貫 3.75キログラム(kg) と定義された。
sen.e: 1 kan was, as a weight unit, equalized with 1000 "monme" (a traditional Japanese weight unit), and in the Meiji period, 1 kan was set at 3.75 kilograms.

sen.e: 1 kan was, as a currency unit, equalized with 1000 "mon," and with 100 "hiki" (mon and hiki were former Japanese currency units).

sen.e: To make a distinction, kan as a weight unit is sometimes called "kanme" (an abbreviation for 1 kan 'mekata' [weight]), and kan as a currency unit is sometimes called "kanmon."

sen.j: 北宋代以降の中国では、開元通宝という唐代の銭貨の質量が、質量の単位基準として用いられ、それを「銭｣（せん）と呼んだ。
sen.e: In China, a copper coin called "Kai Yuan Tong Bao" was minted for the first time in the age of the Tang dynasty, and from the age of Northern Sung dynasty, the coin's weight began to be used as a weight unit called "sen" (in piyin, 'qian').

sen.j: それが日本に伝わり、日本では、一文銭の目方であることから「匁」（もんめ、元は文目）とも呼んだ。
sen.e: This sen was introduced into Japan, where it began to be called "monme" (written as 匁, or - in the past - 文目 in Chinese characters, and 文目 was an abbreviation for 目方 [mekata] of 1 文銭 [monsen] - 'mon' is the above-mentioned currency unit, and 'sen' is coin).

sen.j: 大量の銭を持ち歩く際、持ち運びやすく数えやすいように、銭の中央に空いている穴に紐を通して（貫いて）1000枚を1組としておくということがよく行われた（短陌の場合は960枚）。
sen.e: When a large number of copper coins were carried, it was common that a set of 1000 coins was bundled up with a string at their center hole for convenience of a carry and count - and there existed a simpler version of a set of 960 coins, called "tanhaku."

sen.e: And this was the kan as a currency unit, and the weight of the 1000 coins became the kan as a weight unit.

sen.j: しかし、メートル条約加入後の1891年に制定された度量衡法では、1貫は国際キログラム原器の質量（1キログラム）の 4分の15 (3.75 kg) と定義され、匁はその1000分の1と定められた。
sen.e: After joining the Treaty of the Meter, Japan enacted the Weights and Measures Act in A.D. 1891, which set 1 kan at 3.75 kilograms, or 15/4 of "1 kilogram" (defined by the international prototype of the kilogram), and equalized 1 monme with a thousandth of 1 kan.
